2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTestpack attempts to verify that your npm package is set up properly by\ninstalling the packaged version in a special test folder with its own\ncustom package.json file, and running a copy of your unit tests against it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUsage:\u003c/strong\u003e \u003ccode\u003etestpack [Options] [\u0026lt;Test patterns\u0026gt;]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;Test patterns\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e are glob patterns used to recognize source files that are\ntest-related and so should be copied to the new project. The default test\npatterns are \u003ccode\u003etest* *test.* *tests.* *test*/** tsconfig.json\u003c/code\u003e.\nNote: the \u003ca href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eglob\u003c/code\u003e package\u003c/a\u003e is used to\nmatch test patterns. It requires slash (/) as the path separator even on\nWindows; backslashes escape \"special\" characters such as braces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHere's what it does:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt runs \u003ccode\u003enpm pack\u003c/code\u003e to create a preview copy of your package.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt creates a test folder. By default the folder is \u003cem\u003e../YPN-testpack\u003c/em\u003e\nwhere \u003cem\u003eYPN\u003c/em\u003e is Your Package's Name, and if the test folder already\nexists, its contents are deleted. You can use \u003ccode\u003e--test-folder\u003c/code\u003e to\nchange the folder's path and name.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn the test folder, it creates a new package.json file derived from\nyour existing one, in which all dependencies are deleted except common\nunit test frameworks (e.g. jasmine, mocha, jest). With \u003ccode\u003e--packagejson\u003c/code\u003e\nyou can request additional changes to the new package.json.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt runs \u003ccode\u003enpm install\u003c/code\u003e in the test folder\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt installs any additional packages you requested with \u003ccode\u003e--install\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt unpacks the tgz file generated by \u003ccode\u003enpm pack\u003c/code\u003e using \u003ccode\u003enpm install\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt copies your test files to the new folder, preserving their\noriginal directory structure.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt changes import/require commands in the tests. Except when importing\ntest files, the \"local\" prefix \u003ccode\u003e.\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e..\u003c/code\u003e is changed to the package\nname, so that your tests are importing from \u003cem\u003enode_modules\u003c/em\u003e instead.\nFor example, if your package is called \u003ccode\u003emypkg\u003c/code\u003e and your test code\nsays \u003ccode\u003eimport {...} from \"./module\"\u003c/code\u003e, testpack changes it to\n\u003ccode\u003eimport {...} from \"mypkg/module\"\u003c/code\u003e. You should use the \u003ccode\u003e\"main\"\u003c/code\u003e option\nin package.json to specify the default module, and then you can write\n\u003ccode\u003erequire(\".\")\u003c/code\u003e to import it, which will become \u003ccode\u003erequire(\"mypkg\")\u003c/code\u003e\nin the test folder.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt runs \u003ccode\u003enpm run test\u003c/code\u003e (or another script according to \u003ccode\u003e--test-script\u003c/code\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"--dirty\n      The contents of the test folder are normally deleted at the start.\n      This option skips the deletion step, potentially leaving extra files\n      in the test folder (also: runs faster npm ci instead of npm install)\n--setup-command=command\n      A setup command to run instead of `npm install` (your package is\n      still installed afterward with `npm install ________.tgz` and \n      `npm install` is still used by the `--install` option.) To save\n      time by skipping install when packages in the test folder are \n      already installed, use `--dirty --setup-command=\u0026quot;\u0026quot;`.\n-p, --packagejson=key:value  \n      Merges data into the new package.json file. If the new value is a \n      primitive, it overwrites the old value. If the old value is a \n      primitive, it is treated as an array. If both are arrays, they are\n      concatenated. If either one is an object, they are merged in the \n      obvious way, recursively. For example:\n        Old value: `{\u0026quot;a\u0026quot;:[\u0026quot;hi\u0026quot;], \u0026quot;b\u0026quot;:7, \u0026quot;c\u0026quot;:[3], \u0026quot;x\u0026quot;:{\u0026quot;D\u0026quot;:4}}`\n        New value: `{\u0026quot;a\u0026quot;:1,\u0026quot;b\u0026quot;:[8],\u0026quot;c\u0026quot;:[4],\u0026quot;x\u0026quot;:{\u0026quot;D\u0026quot;:{\u0026quot;two\u0026quot;:2},\u0026quot;E\u0026quot;:5}}`\n        Out: `{\u0026quot;a\u0026quot;:1,\u0026quot;b\u0026quot;:[7,8],\u0026quot;c\u0026quot;:[3,4],\u0026quot;x\u0026quot;:{\u0026quot;D\u0026quot;:{\u0026quot;0\u0026quot;:4,\u0026quot;two\u0026quot;:2},\u0026quot;E\u0026quot;:5}}`\n      You can use `undefined` to delete an existing value, e.g.\n        --packagejson={testpack:undefined,repository:undefined}\n-o, --test-folder=path\n      Path to test folder. Created if necessary.\n-r, --replace-import !pat1!pat2!\n      Searches js/mjs/ts/tsx test files for require/import filenames using \n      regex pattern 1, replacing it with pattern 2. Instead of `!`s you are\n      allowed to use any punctuation mark that doesn't appear in the \n      patterns. Pattern 2 can use $1 through $9 to re-emit captured \n      strings, and $P is replaced with your package's name. Replacements \n      only affect non-test files unless you add --replace-test-imports. \n      If this option is not used then the following default replacement \n      patterns are used:\n        |\\.\\.?|$P| and |\\.\\.?([\\/\\\\].*)|$P$1|\n      Basically, `.` and `..` are replaced with the package name. UTF-8 \n      encoding is assumed in test files, and the regex must match the whole \n      filename unless your regex uses `^` or `$`.\n--regex ext/regex/\n      For the purpose of modifying import/require commands, files with the\n      specified extension(s) are searched using this regular expression,\n      and the first captured group is treated as a filename that may need \n      to be modified. For example, this built-in regex is used to match\n      require commands that use double quotes:\n        --regex js/require\\s*\\(\\s*\u0026quot;((?:[^\\\\\u0026quot;]|\\\\.)*)\u0026quot;/\n      You can specify multiple extensions separated by commas: `js,mjs`\n-R, --rmdir\n      Remove entire test folder when done (by default, only the the tgz\n      produced by `npm pack` is deleted.)\n--delete-on-fail\n      Delete the test folder \u0026amp; tgz even when tests fail.\n-s, --test-script=name\n      Name of test script to run with `npm run` (default: `test`).\n--install package\n      Runs `npm install --save-dev package` in the test project.\n--keep package\n      Prevents removal of package(s) from dependencies or devDependencies.\n--prepacked\n      Skips running `npm pack` and looks for the .tgz file it normally\n      produces (name-version.tgz). This option also prevents the deletion \n      of the tar.gz file on exit.\n--prepacked=file\n      Skips running `npm pack` and unpacks the specified file.\n--show-json\n      Shows the JSON equivalent of the specified arguments, then quits.\n      You can put these settings in a \u0026quot;testpack\u0026quot; section of package.json.\n-!, --nontest pattern\n      Ignores the specified files (glob pattern) when searching for tests.\n-v, --verbose\n      Emits more text describing what testpack is doing.\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e--dirty\n      The contents of the test folder are normally deleted at the start.\n      This option skips the deletion step, potentially leaving extra files\n      in the test folder (also: runs faster npm ci instead of npm install)\n--setup-command=command\n      A setup command to run instead of `npm install` (your package is\n      still installed afterward with `npm install ________.tgz` and \n      `npm install` is still used by the `--install` option.) If either one is an object, they are merged in the \n      obvious way, recursively. For example:\n        Old value: `{\"a\":[\"hi\"], \"b\":7, \"c\":[3], \"x\":{\"D\":4}}`\n        New value: `{\"a\":1,\"b\":[8],\"c\":[4],\"x\":{\"D\":{\"two\":2},\"E\":5}}`\n        Out: `{\"a\":1,\"b\":[7,8],\"c\":[3,4],\"x\":{\"D\":{\"0\":4,\"two\":2},\"E\":5}}`\n      You can use `undefined` to delete an existing value, e.g.\n        --packagejson={testpack:undefined,repository:undefined}\n-o, --test-folder=path\n      Path to test folder. Pattern 2 can use $1 through $9 to re-emit captured \n      strings, and $P is replaced with your package's name. UTF-8 \n      encoding is assumed in test files, and the regex must match the whole \n      filename unless your regex uses `^` or `$`.\n--regex ext/regex/\n      For the purpose of modifying import/require commands, files with the\n      specified extension(s) are searched using this regular expression,\n      and the first captured group is treated as a filename that may need \n      to be modified. \"safePublish\": \"testpack \u0026amp;\u0026amp; npm publish\",\n   ...\n }\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNote:\u003c/strong\u003e It's natural to want to put \u003ccode\u003etestpack --prepacked\u003c/code\u003e in your \u003ccode\u003epostpack\u003c/code\u003e script so it runs after \u003ccode\u003enpm pack\u003c/code\u003e, but this doesn't work because \u003ccode\u003enpm pack\u003c/code\u003e calls \u003ccode\u003epostpack\u003c/code\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://npm.community/t/postpack-script-runs-before-the-tgz-is-packed/592\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ebefore\u003c/em\u003e it produces the tgz file\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf your package includes commands in \u003ccode\u003e\"bin\"\u003c/code\u003e in package.json, npm has an \u003ca href=\"https://npm.community/t/making-a-command-for-a-package-bin/628\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eundocumented requirement for a shebang\u003c/a\u003e. Consider adding some sort of test to make sure your installed command can be invoked (\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/qwertie/testpack/issues\"\u003ecreate an issue\u003c/a\u003e if you want advice).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eTips for TypeScript users\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-tips-for-typescript-users\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Tips for TypeScript users\" href=\"#tips-for-typescript-users\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen publishing TypeScript packages on npm, it’s polite to publish code that has been compiled to JavaScript so that people who are not using TypeScript can still use your package. Here are some things to be aware of:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYou need to use \u003ccode\u003etsc --declaration\u003c/code\u003e (\u003ccode\u003e\"declaration\": true\u003c/code\u003e in tsconfig.json) to create .d.ts typing files which contain type information. After building your .js and .d.ts files, you don’t even need to publish the original TypeScript source code.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen importing a published module, I found that VS Code will detect your typing files (e.g. if \u003ccode\u003e\"main\"\u003c/code\u003e is \u003ccode\u003edist/index.js\u003c/code\u003e then VS Code finds \u003ccode\u003edist/index.d.ts\u003c/code\u003e), \u003ca href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41292559/could-not-find-a-declaration-file-for-module-module-name-path-to-module-nam\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ebut \u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e will not\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. Therefore, before you publish, you need an extra option in package.json such as \u003ccode\u003e\"typings\": \"dist/index\"\u003c/code\u003e to tell \u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e where the d.ts file is (the d.ts extension is inferred.) If you forget the \u003ccode\u003etypings\u003c/code\u003e option, \u003ccode\u003etestpack\u003c/code\u003e can only help you notice your mistake if your unit-testing script includes a type-checking mechanism (certain TypeScript tools such as ts-jest do \u003cstrong\u003enot\u003c/strong\u003e include type checking.)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e may give a baffling error, \"Cannot write file '[your-module].d.ts' because it would overwrite input file\", when your \u003ccode\u003e\"typings\"\u003c/code\u003e option includes the \u003ccode\u003e.d.ts\u003c/code\u003e file extension. So remove that extension!\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe \u003ccode\u003e\"main\"\u003c/code\u003e option in your package.json should refer to a .js file and it's a good idea to use \u003ccode\u003eimport {...} from \".\"\u003c/code\u003e \u003cem\u003ein your tests\u003c/em\u003e to verify that the \u003ccode\u003e\"main\"\u003c/code\u003e option is set correctly. But if you do this, \u003ccode\u003eimport {...} from \".\"\u003c/code\u003e may not work in any modules seen by \u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e because the \u003ccode\u003ejs\u003c/code\u003e file doesn't exist until \u003cem\u003eafter\u003c/em\u003e compilation is finished. You \u003cem\u003emight\u003c/em\u003e solve the problem by stripping off the extension from \u003ccode\u003emain\u003c/code\u003e (e.g. use \u003ccode\u003e\"main\": \"foo\"\u003c/code\u003e instead of \u003ccode\u003e\"main\": \"foo.js\"\u003c/code\u003e). This allows \u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e to use \u003ccode\u003e.ts\u003c/code\u003e as the default file extension while other tools like \u003ccode\u003enode\u003c/code\u003e use \u003ccode\u003e.js\u003c/code\u003e as the default file extension. However, this won't work if your tsconfig.json is configured to place output in a different place (e.g. \u003ccode\u003e\"outDir\": \"dist\"\u003c/code\u003e). In that case, use \u003ccode\u003eimport {...} from \".\"\u003c/code\u003e \u003cem\u003eonly\u003c/em\u003e in your tests and then exclude your tests with the \u003ccode\u003eexclude\u003c/code\u003e option in \u003ca href=\"https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etsconfig.json\u003c/a\u003e, e.g. \u003ccode\u003e\"exclude\": [\"node_modules\", \"**/*.test.ts\"]\u003c/code\u003e. This works if you are running tests with a tool that supports TypeScript but ignores the \u003ccode\u003eexclude\u003c/code\u003e option, such as \u003ccode\u003ets-jest\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003ets-node\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eYou should make sure that the tests which testpack copies to its test folder are importing the compiled JavaScript version, not the TypeScript version. The simplest way to guarantee this is to exclude all .ts files from your package. If you do that, be sure source maps are disabled in your tsconfig.json. In any case, your tests should still be written in TypeScript to make sure that your d.ts files work.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ets-jest users:\u003c/strong\u003e I found it tricky to use ts-jest. In the \u003ccode\u003e\"jest\"\u003c/code\u003e options in package.json, \u003ccode\u003e\"js\"\u003c/code\u003e must be included in the list of \u003ccode\u003e\"moduleFileExtensions\"\u003c/code\u003e, otherwise this error occurs: \"Cannot find module './lib/source-map-generator' from 'source-map.js'\". However we only want to run ts test files, not js files generated by \u003ccode\u003etsc\u003c/code\u003e. The solution I chose was to put tests in their own folder and exclude it in tsconfig.json. But if you exclude your tests from tsconfig.json and then run \u003ccode\u003etestpack\u003c/code\u003e, ts-jest will hit you with \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/kulshekhar/ts-jest/issues/618\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/kulshekhar/ts-jest/issues/618/hovercard\"\u003ebug #618\u003c/a\u003e which the developers declined to fix. To work around this you can teach \u003ccode\u003etestpack\u003c/code\u003e to create a dummy source file in package.json. For example, if tsconfig says your source files are in \u003ccode\u003esrc\u003c/code\u003e, use this:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"  \u0026quot;testpack\u0026quot;: {\n    \u0026quot;packagejson\u0026quot;: {\n      \u0026quot;scripts\u0026quot;: {\n        \u0026quot;fix-ts-jest\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;mkdir src \u0026amp;\u0026amp; echo \\\u0026quot;//avoid ts-jest bug 618\\\u0026quot; \u0026gt; src/dummy.ts || cd .\u0026quot;,\n        \u0026quot;test\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;npm run fix-ts-jest \u0026amp;\u0026amp; jest\u0026quot;\n      }\n    }\n  }\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e  \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003e\"testpack\"\u003c/span\u003e: {\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003e\"packagejson\"\u003c/span\u003e: {\n      \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003e\"scripts\"\u003c/span\u003e: {\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003e\"fix-ts-jest\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003emkdir src \u0026amp;\u0026amp; echo \u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\\"\u003c/span\u003e//avoid ts-jest bug 618\u003cspan class=\"pl-cce\"\u003e\\\"\u003c/span\u003e \u0026gt; src/dummy.ts || cd .\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e,\n        \u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003e\"test\"\u003c/span\u003e: \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003enpm run fix-ts-jest \u0026amp;\u0026amp; jest\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n      }\n    }\n  }\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003etestpack-cli versus package-preview\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-testpack-cli-versus-package-preview\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: testpack-cli versus package-preview\" href=\"#testpack-cli-versus-package-preview\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eI created testpack because I wasn't happy with package-preview. Package-preview \u003cem\u003edoes not\u003c/em\u003e create a special test folder and it \u003cem\u003ecannot\u003c/em\u003e edit the \u003ccode\u003eimport\u003c/code\u003e/\u003ccode\u003erequire\u003c/code\u003e commands in your source files. Instead, package-preview seems to be designed with the assumption that it will \u003cem\u003ealways\u003c/em\u003e run before your tests. However, your package may need to be built (with Babel or TypeScript) before it is packaged, and package-preview installs it with a \u003cem\u003eseparate copy\u003c/em\u003e of all the dependencies of your package. This is usually a slow process - a process you don't want to run \u003cem\u003eevery time\u003c/em\u003e you run your unit tests.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor example, I wrote \u003ca href=\"https://www.npmjs.com/package/simplertime\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ea very simple package\u003c/a\u003e whose unit tests took 1 second. Once I added package-preview, I needed 18 seconds to run package-preview before the unit tests could start.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUnfortunately, I couldn't find any way to import a module from \u003cem\u003enode_modules\u003c/em\u003e if the path started with \u003ccode\u003e./\u003c/code\u003e - that prefix seems to be treated as proof that it's not in \u003cem\u003enode_modules\u003c/em\u003e. Likewise, I couldn't find any way import a module from the current directory if it \u003cstrong\u003edid not\u003c/strong\u003e start with \u003ccode\u003e./\u003c/code\u003e. In normal JavaScript you could try using environment variables to figure out whether you need to use \u003ccode\u003e.\u003c/code\u003e or not, e.g. \u003ccode\u003erequire(process.env.TESTPACK ? \"mymodule\" : \"./index\")\u003c/code\u003e. However if you are using TypeScript or \u003ccode\u003eimport\u003c/code\u003e statements, this is not possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThus, the purpose of \u003ccode\u003etestpack\u003c/code\u003e is to avoid slowing down the \u003cem\u003enormal\u003c/em\u003e unit test process when you are \u003cem\u003enot about to publish\u003c/em\u003e. Your tests can import a local copy of your code from \u003ccode\u003e./\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e../\u003c/code\u003e so they run quickly. When you're ready to publish, you use the slower \u003ccode\u003etestpack\u003c/code\u003e process to create a special-purpose test environment with modified imports.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNote:\u003c/strong\u003e I bet one of you JavaScript wizards knows how I could have avoided all this trouble with \u003ccode\u003e./\u003c/code\u003e. TypeScript users might think that \u003ca href=\"https://stackoverflow.com/a/38677886/22820\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTypeScript aliases\u003c/a\u003e could potentially solve this problem, but they can't because they are compile-time only. That is, if you tell TypeScript that \u003ccode\u003e./A\u003c/code\u003e is an alias for \u003ccode\u003eB\u003c/code\u003e, then TypeScript loads \u003ccode\u003eB\u003c/code\u003e for type checking but it generates code that still refers to \u003ccode\u003e./A\u003c/code\u003e! And \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/138\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/138/hovercard\"\u003ets-node inherits this problem\u003c/a\u003e; thus if you are writing code for the command line / Node.js, aliases don't seem to help at all.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePackage-preview does have one special virtue: it uses \u003ccode\u003epnpm\u003c/code\u003e to isolate the packed package (i.e. the almost-published tgz) from any other packages installed in the same project that are \u003cem\u003enot\u003c/em\u003e declared as dependencies in the packed package. Testpack doesn't have as much isolation, e.g. it keeps unit test frameworks. So, suppose that your packed package tries to use a dependency X but it doesn't declare the dependency in package.json like it should. If your unit test framework also uses dependency X, your code may still work when it should actually break. I apologize for that but I don't have time to implement fancier isolation. Perhaps someone will make a pull request?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eVersion \u003ccode\u003e--setup-command\u003c/code\u003e option.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eChanged how imports are transformed. Initially the prefix \u003ccode\u003e./\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e../\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e../src\u003c/code\u003e was simply stripped off, but in v1.1 \u003ccode\u003e.\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e..\u003c/code\u003e is replaced with the package name, and \u003ccode\u003esrc\u003c/code\u003e is no longer treated specially.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003ev1.0.3\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca 0 0 1 0 2Z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="Box-sc-g0xbh4-0 bJMeLZ js-snippet-clipboard-copy-unpositioned" data-hpc="true"><article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h1 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">testpack: Test your package before publishing</h1><a id="user-content-testpack-test-your-package-before-publishing" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: testpack: Test your package before publishing" href="#testpack-test-your-package-before-publishing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Testpack attempts to verify that your npm package is set up properly byinstalling the packaged version in a special test folder with its owncustom package.json file, and running a copy of your unit tests against it.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Usage:</strong> <code>testpack [Options] [<Test patterns>]</code></p><p dir="auto"><code><Test patterns></code> are glob patterns used to recognize source files that aretest-related and so should be copied to the new project. The default testpatterns are <code>test* *test.* *tests.* *test*/** tsconfig.json</code>.Note: the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob" rel="nofollow"><code>glob</code> package</a> is used tomatch test patterns. It requires slash (/) as the path separator even onWindows; backslashes escape "special" characters such as braces.</p><p dir="auto">Here's what it does:</p><ol dir="auto"><li>It runs <code>npm pack</code> to create a preview copy of your package.</li><li>It creates a test folder. By default the folder is <em>../YPN-testpack</em>where <em>YPN</em> is Your Package's Name, and if the test folder alreadyexists, its contents are deleted. You can use <code>--test-folder</code> tochange the folder's path and name.</li><li>In the test folder, it creates a new package.json file derived fromyour existing one, in which all dependencies are deleted except commonunit test frameworks (e.g. jasmine, mocha, jest). With <code>--packagejson</code>you can request additional changes to the new package.json.</li><li>It runs <code>npm install</code> in the test folder</li><li>It installs any additional packages you requested with <code>--install</code></li><li>It unpacks the tgz file generated by <code>npm pack</code> using <code>npm install</code></li><li>It copies your test files to the new folder, preserving theiroriginal directory structure.</li><li>It changes import/require commands in the tests. Except when importingtest files, the "local" prefix <code>.</code> or <code>..</code> is changed to the packagename, so that your tests are importing from <em>node_modules</em> instead.For example, if your package is called <code>mypkg</code> and your test codesays <code>import {...} from "./module"</code>, testpack changes it to<code>import {...} from "mypkg/module"</code>. You should use the <code>"main"</code> optionin package.json to specify the default module, and then you can write<code>require(".")</code> to import it, which will become <code>require("mypkg")</code>in the test folder.</li><li>It runs <code>npm run test</code> (or another script according to <code>--test-script</code>)</li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Options</h2><a id="user-content-options" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Options" href="#options"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">All command-line options are optional.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="--dirty      The contents of the test folder are normally deleted at the start.      This option skips the deletion step, potentially leaving extra files      in the test folder (also: runs faster npm ci instead of npm install)--setup-command=command      A setup command to run instead of `npm install` (your package is      still installed afterward with `npm install ________.tgz` and       `npm install` is still used by the `--install` option.) To save      time by skipping install when packages in the test folder are       already installed, use `--dirty --setup-command=""`.-p, --packagejson=key:value        Merges data into the new package.json file. If the new value is a       primitive, it overwrites the old value. If the old value is a       primitive, it is treated as an array. If both are arrays, they are      concatenated. If either one is an object, they are merged in the       obvious way, recursively. For example:        Old value: `{"a":["hi"], "b":7, "c":[3], "x":{"D":4}}`        New value: `{"a":1,"b":[8],"c":[4],"x":{"D":{"two":2},"E":5}}`        Out: `{"a":1,"b":[7,8],"c":[3,4],"x":{"D":{"0":4,"two":2},"E":5}}`      You can use `undefined` to delete an existing value, e.g.        --packagejson={testpack:undefined,repository:undefined}-o, --test-folder=path      Path to test folder. Created if necessary.-r, --replace-import !pat1!pat2!      Searches js/mjs/ts/tsx test files for require/import filenames using       regex pattern 1, replacing it with pattern 2. Instead of `!`s you are      allowed to use any punctuation mark that doesn't appear in the       patterns. Pattern 2 can use $1 through $9 to re-emit captured       strings, and $P is replaced with your package's name. Replacements       only affect non-test files unless you add --replace-test-imports.       If this option is not used then the following default replacement       patterns are used:        |\.\.?|$P| and |\.\.?([\/\\].*)|$P$1|      Basically, `.` and `..` are replaced with the package name. UTF-8       encoding is assumed in test files, and the regex must match the whole       filename unless your regex uses `^` or `$`.--regex ext/regex/      For the purpose of modifying import/require commands, files with the      specified extension(s) are searched using this regular expression,      and the first captured group is treated as a filename that may need       to be modified. For example, this built-in regex is used to match      require commands that use double quotes:        --regex js/require\s*\(\s*"((?:[^\\"]|\\.)*)"/      You can specify multiple extensions separated by commas: `js,mjs`-R, --rmdir      Remove entire test folder when done (by default, only the the tgz      produced by `npm pack` is deleted.)--delete-on-fail      Delete the test folder & tgz even when tests fail.-s, --test-script=name      Name of test script to run with `npm run` (default: `test`).--install package      Runs `npm install --save-dev package` in the test project.--keep package      Prevents removal of package(s) from dependencies or devDependencies.--prepacked      Skips running `npm pack` and looks for the .tgz file it normally      produces (name-version.tgz). This option also prevents the deletion       of the tar.gz file on exit.--prepacked=file      Skips running `npm pack` and unpacks the specified file.--show-json      Shows the JSON equivalent of the specified arguments, then quits.      You can put these settings in a "testpack" section of package.json.-!, --nontest pattern      Ignores the specified files (glob pattern) when searching for tests.-v, --verbose      Emits more text describing what testpack is doing."><pre class="notranslate"><code>--dirty      The contents of the test folder are normally deleted at the start.      This option skips the deletion step, potentially leaving extra files      in the test folder (also: runs faster npm ci instead of npm install)--setup-command=command      A setup command to run instead of `npm install` (your package is      still installed afterward with `npm install ________.tgz` and       `npm install` is still used by the `--install` option.) To save      time by skipping install when packages in the test folder are       already installed, use `--dirty --setup-command=""`.-p, --packagejson=key:value        Merges data into the new package.json file. If the new value is a       primitive, it overwrites the old value. If the old value is a       primitive, it is treated as an array. If both are arrays, they are      concatenated. If either one is an object, they are merged in the       obvious way, recursively. For example:        Old value: `{"a":["hi"], "b":7, "c":[3], "x":{"D":4}}`        New value: `{"a":1,"b":[8],"c":[4],"x":{"D":{"two":2},"E":5}}`        Out: `{"a":1,"b":[7,8],"c":[3,4],"x":{"D":{"0":4,"two":2},"E":5}}`      You can use `undefined` to delete an existing value, e.g.        --packagejson={testpack:undefined,repository:undefined}-o, --test-folder=path      Path to test folder. Created if necessary.-r, --replace-import !pat1!pat2!      Searches js/mjs/ts/tsx test files for require/import filenames using       regex pattern 1, replacing it with pattern 2. Instead of `!`s you are      allowed to use any punctuation mark that doesn't appear in the       patterns. Pattern 2 can use $1 through $9 to re-emit captured       strings, and $P is replaced with your package's name. Replacements       only affect non-test files unless you add --replace-test-imports.       If this option is not used then the following default replacement       patterns are used:        |\.\.?|$P| and |\.\.?([\/\\].*)|$P$1|      Basically, `.` and `..` are replaced with the package name. UTF-8       encoding is assumed in test files, and the regex must match the whole       filename unless your regex uses `^` or `$`.--regex ext/regex/      For the purpose of modifying import/require commands, files with the      specified extension(s) are searched using this regular expression,      and the first captured group is treated as a filename that may need       to be modified. For example, this built-in regex is used to match      require commands that use double quotes:        --regex js/require\s*\(\s*"((?:[^\\"]|\\.)*)"/      You can specify multiple extensions separated by commas: `js,mjs`-R, --rmdir      Remove entire test folder when done (by default, only the the tgz      produced by `npm pack` is deleted.)--delete-on-fail      Delete the test folder & tgz even when tests fail.-s, --test-script=name      Name of test script to run with `npm run` (default: `test`).--install package      Runs `npm install --save-dev package` in the test project.--keep package      Prevents removal of package(s) from dependencies or devDependencies.--prepacked      Skips running `npm pack` and looks for the .tgz file it normally      produces (name-version.tgz). This option also prevents the deletion       of the tar.gz file on exit.--prepacked=file      Skips running `npm pack` and unpacks the specified file.--show-json      Shows the JSON equivalent of the specified arguments, then quits.      You can put these settings in a "testpack" section of package.json.-!, --nontest pattern      Ignores the specified files (glob pattern) when searching for tests.-v, --verbose      Emits more text describing what testpack is doing.</code></pre></div><p dir="auto"><strong>Caution:</strong> your shell may transform special characters before they reachtestpack. For example, on Windows, <code>--packagejson=key:"value"</code> doesn't workbecause the shell removes the quotes, causing an error message from testpack.</p><p dir="auto">If you prefer, options can be placed in a <code>"testpack"</code> section of yourpackage.json file. For example,</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="  "testpack": { "test-script":"foo", "verbose": true }"><pre>  <span class="pl-ent">"testpack"</span>: { <span class="pl-ent">"test-script"</span>:<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>foo<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-ent">"verbose"</span>: <span class="pl-c1">true</span> }</pre></div><p dir="auto">is equivalent to <code>--test-script=foo --verbose</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">How to use testpack</h2><a id="user-content-how-to-use-testpack" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: How to use testpack" href="#how-to-use-testpack"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ol dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Prepare to your package for publishing as you normally would (<a href="http://typescript-react-primer.loyc.net/publish-npm-package.html" rel="nofollow">guide</a>)</p></li><li><p dir="auto">In a terminal: <code>npm install --save-dev --global testpack-cli</code></p></li><li><p dir="auto">Run it with: <code>testpack</code> (add <code>--verbose</code> for more detail)</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Run <code>npm publish</code> once your tests pass.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">To combine steps 4 and 5, use a script like <code>npm run safePublish</code> :</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=" "scripts": {   "safePublish": "testpack && npm publish",   ... }"><pre class="notranslate"><code> "scripts": {   "safePublish": "testpack && npm publish",   ... }</code></pre></div></li></ol><p dir="auto"><strong>Note:</strong> It's natural to want to put <code>testpack --prepacked</code> in your <code>postpack</code> script so it runs after <code>npm pack</code>, but this doesn't work because <code>npm pack</code> calls <code>postpack</code> <a href="https://npm.community/t/postpack-script-runs-before-the-tgz-is-packed/592" rel="nofollow"><em>before</em> it produces the tgz file</a>.</p><p dir="auto">If your package includes commands in <code>"bin"</code> in package.json, npm has an <a href="https://npm.community/t/making-a-command-for-a-package-bin/628" rel="nofollow">undocumented requirement for a shebang</a>. Consider adding some sort of test to make sure your installed command can be invoked (<a href="https://github.com/qwertie/testpack/issues">create an issue</a> if you want advice).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Tips for TypeScript users</h2><a id="user-content-tips-for-typescript-users" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Tips for TypeScript users" href="#tips-for-typescript-users"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When publishing TypeScript packages on npm, it’s polite to publish code that has been compiled to JavaScript so that people who are not using TypeScript can still use your package. Here are some things to be aware of:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>You need to use <code>tsc --declaration</code> (<code>"declaration": true</code> in tsconfig.json) to create .d.ts typing files which contain type information. After building your .js and .d.ts files, you don’t even need to publish the original TypeScript source code.</li><li>When importing a published module, I found that VS Code will detect your typing files (e.g. if <code>"main"</code> is <code>dist/index.js</code> then VS Code finds <code>dist/index.d.ts</code>), <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41292559/could-not-find-a-declaration-file-for-module-module-name-path-to-module-nam" rel="nofollow"><strong>but <code>tsc</code> will not</strong></a>. Therefore, before you publish, you need an extra option in package.json such as <code>"typings": "dist/index"</code> to tell <code>tsc</code> where the d.ts file is (the d.ts extension is inferred.) If you forget the <code>typings</code> option, <code>testpack</code> can only help you notice your mistake if your unit-testing script includes a type-checking mechanism (certain TypeScript tools such as ts-jest do <strong>not</strong> include type checking.)</li><li><code>tsc</code> may give a baffling error, "Cannot write file '[your-module].d.ts' because it would overwrite input file", when your <code>"typings"</code> option includes the <code>.d.ts</code> file extension. So remove that extension!</li><li>The <code>"main"</code> option in your package.json should refer to a .js file and it's a good idea to use <code>import {...} from "."</code> <em>in your tests</em> to verify that the <code>"main"</code> option is set correctly. But if you do this, <code>import {...} from "."</code> may not work in any modules seen by <code>tsc</code> because the <code>js</code> file doesn't exist until <em>after</em> compilation is finished. You <em>might</em> solve the problem by stripping off the extension from <code>main</code> (e.g. use <code>"main": "foo"</code> instead of <code>"main": "foo.js"</code>). This allows <code>tsc</code> to use <code>.ts</code> as the default file extension while other tools like <code>node</code> use <code>.js</code> as the default file extension. However, this won't work if your tsconfig.json is configured to place output in a different place (e.g. <code>"outDir": "dist"</code>). In that case, use <code>import {...} from "."</code> <em>only</em> in your tests and then exclude your tests with the <code>exclude</code> option in <a href="https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/tsconfig-json.html" rel="nofollow">tsconfig.json</a>, e.g. <code>"exclude": ["node_modules", "**/*.test.ts"]</code>. This works if you are running tests with a tool that supports TypeScript but ignores the <code>exclude</code> option, such as <code>ts-jest</code> or <code>ts-node</code>.</li><li>You should make sure that the tests which testpack copies to its test folder are importing the compiled JavaScript version, not the TypeScript version. The simplest way to guarantee this is to exclude all .ts files from your package. If you do that, be sure source maps are disabled in your tsconfig.json. In any case, your tests should still be written in TypeScript to make sure that your d.ts files work.</li></ul><p dir="auto"><strong>ts-jest users:</strong> I found it tricky to use ts-jest. In the <code>"jest"</code> options in package.json, <code>"js"</code> must be included in the list of <code>"moduleFileExtensions"</code>, otherwise this error occurs: "Cannot find module './lib/source-map-generator' from 'source-map.js'". However we only want to run ts test files, not js files generated by <code>tsc</code>. The solution I chose was to put tests in their own folder and exclude it in tsconfig.json. But if you exclude your tests from tsconfig.json and then run <code>testpack</code>, ts-jest will hit you with <a href="https://github.com/kulshekhar/ts-jest/issues/618" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/kulshekhar/ts-jest/issues/618/hovercard">bug #618</a> which the developers declined to fix. To work around this you can teach <code>testpack</code> to create a dummy source file in package.json. For example, if tsconfig says your source files are in <code>src</code>, use this:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="  "testpack": {    "packagejson": {      "scripts": {        "fix-ts-jest": "mkdir src && echo \"//avoid ts-jest bug 618\" > src/dummy.ts || cd .",        "test": "npm run fix-ts-jest && jest"      }    }  }"><pre>  <span class="pl-ent">"testpack"</span>: {    <span class="pl-ent">"packagejson"</span>: {      <span class="pl-ent">"scripts"</span>: {        <span class="pl-ent">"fix-ts-jest"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>mkdir src && echo <span class="pl-cce">\"</span>//avoid ts-jest bug 618<span class="pl-cce">\"</span> > src/dummy.ts || cd .<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,        <span class="pl-ent">"test"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>npm run fix-ts-jest && jest<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>      }    }  }</pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">testpack-cli versus package-preview</h2><a id="user-content-testpack-cli-versus-package-preview" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: testpack-cli versus package-preview" href="#testpack-cli-versus-package-preview"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">I created testpack because I wasn't happy with package-preview. Package-preview <em>does not</em> create a special test folder and it <em>cannot</em> edit the <code>import</code>/<code>require</code> commands in your source files. Instead, package-preview seems to be designed with the assumption that it will <em>always</em> run before your tests. However, your package may need to be built (with Babel or TypeScript) before it is packaged, and package-preview installs it with a <em>separate copy</em> of all the dependencies of your package. This is usually a slow process - a process you don't want to run <em>every time</em> you run your unit tests.</p><p dir="auto">For example, I wrote <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/simplertime" rel="nofollow">a very simple package</a> whose unit tests took 1 second. Once I added package-preview, I needed 18 seconds to run package-preview before the unit tests could start.</p><p dir="auto">Unfortunately, I couldn't find any way to import a module from <em>node_modules</em> if the path started with <code>./</code> - that prefix seems to be treated as proof that it's not in <em>node_modules</em>. Likewise, I couldn't find any way import a module from the current directory if it <strong>did not</strong> start with <code>./</code>. In normal JavaScript you could try using environment variables to figure out whether you need to use <code>.</code> or not, e.g. <code>require(process.env.TESTPACK ? "mymodule" : "./index")</code>. However if you are using TypeScript or <code>import</code> statements, this is not possible.</p><p dir="auto">Thus, the purpose of <code>testpack</code> is to avoid slowing down the <em>normal</em> unit test process when you are <em>not about to publish</em>. Your tests can import a local copy of your code from <code>./</code> or <code>../</code> so they run quickly. When you're ready to publish, you use the slower <code>testpack</code> process to create a special-purpose test environment with modified imports.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Note:</strong> I bet one of you JavaScript wizards knows how I could have avoided all this trouble with <code>./</code>. TypeScript users might think that <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/38677886/22820" rel="nofollow">TypeScript aliases</a> could potentially solve this problem, but they can't because they are compile-time only. That is, if you tell TypeScript that <code>./A</code> is an alias for <code>B</code>, then TypeScript loads <code>B</code> for type checking but it generates code that still refers to <code>./A</code>! And <a href="https://github.com/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/138" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/TypeStrong/ts-node/issues/138/hovercard">ts-node inherits this problem</a>; thus if you are writing code for the command line / Node.js, aliases don't seem to help at all.</p><p dir="auto">Package-preview does have one special virtue: it uses <code>pnpm</code> to isolate the packed package (i.e. the almost-published tgz) from any other packages installed in the same project that are <em>not</em> declared as dependencies in the packed package. Testpack doesn't have as much isolation, e.g. it keeps unit test frameworks. So, suppose that your packed package tries to use a dependency X but it doesn't declare the dependency in package.json like it should. If your unit test framework also uses dependency X, your code may still work when it should actually break. I apologize for that but I don't have time to implement fancier isolation. Perhaps someone will make a pull request?</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Version history</h2><a id="user-content-version-history"
